The loss of chunk border packs has made making large to mid sized redstone devices annoying.
Redstone is currently my preferred project in survival realm. However without constantly calculation of chunk boundaries I run a very high risk of them malfunctioning or completely breaking whenever I travel out of the build area.

I have spoken to other bedrock redstone enthusiasts that have left the game completely after suffering similar problems.

Given the state of how impossible it is to obtain RTX grade GPUs for most players is one HUGE reason this should be worked on immediately by the Mojang team. I would add to this point on the graphical side too that most of the available RTX packs are buggy and incomplete making even that experience...ho hum at best. 
   Additionally if the game is seeking parity between versions, the inability to have "F3" functionality in Bedrock means finding things like chunk borders a chore on the Bedrock version compared to the relative ease in doing this in Java. This is only one of many examples that exist.
   Handcuffing Bedrock players only hurts the overall community. The Java platform will remain the "go to" platform for players if functionality that players desire is taken away which seems counterintuitive to the push for parity and growth of the game for both new comers and say more technical players.

The utility aspect is what matters the most to me.  I do want to use RTX because, frankly, it looks awesome.  However, I also want the ability to see chunk borders and light levels, redstone guides, etc.  Most of these utilities are just built into Java Edition.  Those same features aren't available to us in Bedrock Edition.  Shaders were the only way to accomplish that but now we can't even do that.

I don't know enough about the Render Dragon technology to know whether third party shaders can take take advantage of the RTX features but it would seem to me that, if they can, that would only drive more usage and more players.   I would love to see this support added.  Of course, I also wouldn't mind seeing the debug screen and its related tools added to Bedrock as well.

Does Render Dragon support community shaders?  

Currently, Render Dragon does not support 3rd party community shaders. Any community shaders previously used on Minecraft for Windows 10 may not run on a Render Dragon version of the game.

I support this new graphical update, having dragon render for game optimization, support coming to mobile phones as well. Many people say that be shaders are rubbish and fake. The fundamental reason is that mojang blocks the shaders interface, resulting in few things that shader writers can use. The result is that each shader has flash points, but the overall effect is similar. It's easy to make these effects in JE, but in be, these effects are difficult to achieve in a short time even if the top JE shaders author comes.

Redstone auxiliary tools are also realized by shaders. For example, block boundary display, Redstone energy display, shielding particles / fog, compass and other effects.

The same is true for those magnificent maps. Without the blessing of shaders, the authenticity will be greatly reduced. It is too laggy to say that official chasing can satisfy them, but the official style of tracking is not enough to satisfy the real and magnificent demands of such maps.

Therefore, I hope the official can restore this function in the bedrock edition.

Alright guys, It's been more than a year since I've posted this suggestion. Thanks for all of the support for this idea, I really apreciate it. Now, I will create the summary of the suggestions from you guys and more suggestions from myself too. And also, I'm sorry in this comment there are no visual explanation for these suggestions.


Summary of Suggestions :

1. Player Model Size

"Mabe instead of 2x3 block skins, just like 1.25x2.25." - GiantNuker

That was a better size limit! It would make the model make more sense. and also, my friend said that the minimum size should be 1x1.75, because if it's in a multiplayer server, other player might have a hard time looking for the player with a 1x1.5 model size.

2. Server Integrations

"I think though that you should be able to have parts of the body that are invisible but you can't use that skin on a server." - LuigiLikesBagel

Hmmm... Maybe servers should use an option to Allow the players to use custom 3D Model or not, Oh! and Java edition players might need to have an original minecraft model skin in order to add a custom 3d model, so they can join a Server with Custom Model Option disabled easily. For Bedrock edition will be even easier because of in-game skin selections.

3. Armor, Elytra, and Cape

"Once, on a server, I saw a player with a tiny custom-model skin (Yoda), and they were on Skywar or something, and they were very hard to see, and the item held and the armor were INVISIBLE." - CoderTommy

I definitely didn't thought about armor, elytra, and cape before. My friend suggested that it needs to be shown on the involved bones (for armor, it might need to be overlayed on top of head, body, arms, and legs. for elytra and cape might need to be overlayed on body, just like hat on the head, jacket on the body, etc.). But, I think elytra and cape should be disabled(Invisible) for custom 3d model. And armor might still need to be overlayed on top of the skin.

4. In-Game Store

"Of course, it probably won't because one issue is that Microsoft will lose money because no one will buy skin packs." - STORoguePatron

Come on Microsoft, isn't Minecraft a game for creativity? don't make people limited from their creativity because of money. Maybe if Microsoft & Mojang have reimplemented custom 3D model, they would have made even more money because of skin creators selling their creations through In-Game Store.

A much simplified version, though not as versatile, could easily allow at least some added flexibility which could be turned on or off in different servers and still allow the same Avatar to be used. As an example, imagine each part of the avatar could be scaled up or down in any direction relative to the other parts, or looked at another way each part could be scaled up or down and the complete Avatar would be scaled up or down in the same direction whatever amount is necessary to bring the Avatar back to its original full proportions. Likewise, an entire part could be essentially turned off, or shrunken down so far that it's effectively turned off. By the way, I don't understand why these things are called 4D or 5D, since I don't see anything about them that fits such a description, but what I have seen most people referring to as 4D Avatar skins seems to be simply an animated skin concept, which should be easily facilitated with animated PNG since the avatars are stored in PNG files. Minecraft is a bit different from other ray-traced games because it uses full path-tracing for every lighting technique. This means that there are a lot more rays and ray bounces to calculate than other ray traced games such as Spiderman Miles Morales or Cyberpunk 2077. Due to this, the game heavily depends on upscaling to created a playable experience on lower end hardware. Currently AMD's ray acceleration hardware is significantly less powerful than Nvidia's and AMD haven't released anything to compete with DLSS, so a proper implementation of Minecraft RTX on those consoles would probably require AMD to release a DLSS competitor.

Arctic wolves would obviously be best placed in the snowy tundra/snowy mountains (and maybe they can share the snow taiga with the grey/traditional wolves as well). Red wolves can thrive in a pretty wild variety of environments, namely forests, swamps, and coastal prairies. As someone who's tinkered with programming for almost 8 years, I want to confirm to OP that what you said is MOSTLY correct, except for the fact that a cubs isnt a polygon - its a collection of them. Each face of a cube is comprised of two triangles - totaling 12 polygons per cube, however, this of course is a ludicrous poly count that even the beefiest computers would struggle to draw a single chunk. Instead, what Minecraft does under the hood is build chunks into a single 3D model via an algorithm. It occludes the faces that you wont be able to see (aka, doesnt add them to the model). This is why sometimes there are lag spikes when you destroy or place a block - your computer has to rebuild the chunk's geometry to show the hole you just dug / add the geometry for the block you just placed. You can get an idea of what the models really look like when you are in spectator mode, like when you can see caves but no dirt around you, because in normal gameplay conditions, you should never see the dirt block you are currently inside of

 

What LODs do is simplify the models one step further - which would result in smooth terrain, but from the naked eye, it doesnt really matter in terms of aesthetic

 

So yes, MC definitely needs LODs, like desperately.

One potential way to do it, though I don't know how practical it is to do, would be to reduce the poly count of each cubic chunk to a set of overlapping polys, 17 on each axis, which would reduce the count from a possible count of 512 for a flat plane to only 2 for that same space, each with a block of offset for a total of 102 polys each with the colors being the average color of each block, mipmapping if necessary and partial transparency included where applicable, on an auto-generated 16x16 texture with complete transparency used where no blocks are present, possibly using a look-up table, removing any polys that don't have a visible texture on either side to reduce those that are unnecessary, and reducing to every other block, 54 polys, every 4th block, 30 polys, half-chunk, 18 polys, and full chunk, 12 polys, when moving further away, with their textures showing the colors of the blocks that would be visible from the player's perspective without reducing the visual quality too much until it would be difficult to see for anyone.
